description: From Middle English hōm, from Old English hām, from Proto-West Germanic *haim, from Proto-Germanic *haimaz (“home, village”), from Proto-Indo-European *tḱóymos (“village, home”), from the root *tḱey-.

entries.meaning: Of, from, or pertaining to one’s dwelling or country; domestic; not foreign [from 13th c.]
(now rare, except in phrases) That strikes home; direct, pointed. [from 17th c.]
(obsolete) Personal, intimate. [17th–19th c.]
examples: I hardly knew what I answered him, but, by degrees I tranquillised, as I found he forbore distressing me any further, by such Home strokes […].

entries.meaning: (sports) Relating to the home team (the team at whose venue a game is played). [from 19th c.]
examples: the home end, home advantage, home supporters

entries.meaning: To one's place of residence or one's customary or official location
To one's place of birth
To the place where it belongs; to the end of a course; to the full length
(Internet) To the home page
At or in one's place of residence or one's customary or official location; at home
examples: Everyone's gone to watch the game; there's nobody home.

entries.meaning: To a full and intimate degree; to the heart of the matter; fully, directly.
examples: I do now publish my Essays; which of all my other works have been most current : for that, as it seems, they come home to men's business and bosoms.

entries.meaning: (UK, soccer) into the goal
examples: Walker was penalised for a picking up a Gerry Taggart backpass and from the resulting free-kick, Keane fired home after Johnnie Jackson's initial effort was blocked.

entries.meaning: (nautical) into the right, proper or stowed position
One’s own dwelling place; the house or structure in which one lives; especially the house in which one lives with one's family; the habitual abode of one’s family.
examples: Thither for ease and soft repose we come: / Home is the sacred refuge of our life; / Secured from all approaches, but a wife.

entries.meaning: The place (residence, settlement, country, etc.), where a person was born and/or raised; childhood or parental home; home of one’s parents or guardian.
examples: The rights listed in the UNCRC cover all areas of children's lives such as their right to have a home and their right to be educated.

entries.meaning: The abiding place of the affections, especially of the domestic affections.
examples: He enter’d in the house—his home no more, / For without hearts there is no home; […]

entries.meaning: A house that has been made home-like, to suit the comfort of those who live there.
examples: It's what you bring into a house that makes it a home

entries.meaning: A place of refuge, rest or care; an asylum.
examples: Instead of a pet store, get your new dog from the local dogs’ home.

entries.meaning: (by extension) The grave; the final rest; also, the native and eternal dwelling place of the soul.
examples: […] because man goeth to his long home, and the mourners go about the streets:  […]

entries.meaning: One’s native land; the place or country in which one dwells; the place where one’s ancestors dwell or dwelt.
examples: Visiting these famous localities, and a great many others, I hope that I do not compromise my American patriotism by acknowledging that I was often conscious of a fervent hereditary attachment to the native soil of our forefathers, and felt it to be our own Old Home.

entries.meaning: The locality where a thing is usually found, or was first found, or where it is naturally abundant; habitat; seat.
(board games) The ultimate point aimed at in a progress; the goal.
examples: The object of Sorry! is to get all four of your pawns to your home.

entries.meaning: (baseball) Home plate.
(lacrosse) The place of a player in front of an opponent’s goal; also, the player.
(Internet) The landing page of a website; the site's homepage.
(music, informal) The chord at which a melody starts and to which it can resolve.
(computing) Clipping of home directory.

verbs.description: home (third-person singular simple present homes, present participle homing, simple past and past participle homed)

entries.meaning: (of animals, transitive) To return to its owner.
(always with "in on", transitive) To seek or aim for something.
examples: The missile was able to home in on the target.
